summary.p: The STANDARD mode provides the latest recommended default values that should be safe to run in most scenarios
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The IN_REGION mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for applications which call AWS services from within the same AWS region
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The CROSS_REGION mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for applications which call AWS services in a different region
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The MOBILE mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for mobile applications
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The AUTO mode is an experimental mode that builds on the standard mode. The SDK will attempt to discover the execution environment to determine the appropriate settings automatically.

Note that the auto detection is heuristics-based and does not guarantee 100% accuracy. STANDARD mode will be used if the execution environment cannot be determined. The auto detection might query EC2 Instance Metadata service, which might introduce latency. Therefore we recommend choosing an explicit defaults_mode instead if startup latency is critical to your application
The LEGACY mode provides default settings that vary per SDK and were used prior to establishment of defaults_mode

member.name: T:Amazon.EMRServerless.Internal.AmazonEMRServerlessEndpointResolver
member.summary: Amazon EMRServerless endpoint resolver. Custom PipelineHandler responsible for resolving endpoint and setting authentication parameters for EMRServerless service requests. Collects values for EMRServerlessEndpointParameters and then tries to resolve endpoint by calling ResolveEndpoint method on GlobalEndpoints.Provider if present, otherwise uses EMRServerlessEndpointProvider. Responsible for setting authentication and http headers provided by resolved endpoint.

Array Members Valid Values: STDOUT, STDERR, HIVE_LOG, TEZ_AM, SYSTEM_LOGS

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkerTypeSpecifications.
The key-value pairs that specify worker type to WorkerTypeSpecificationInput. This parameter must contain all valid worker types for a Spark or Hive application. Valid worker types include Driver and Executor for Spark applications and HiveDriver and TezTask for Hive applications. You can either set image details in this parameter for each worker type, or in imageConfiguration for all worker types.

member.name: T:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.GetDashboardForJobRunRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetDashboardForJobRun operation. Creates and returns a URL that you can use to access the application UIs for a job run.
For jobs in a running state, the application UI is a live user interface such as the Spark or Tez web UI. For completed jobs, the application UI is a persistent application user interface such as the Spark History Server or persistent Tez UI.
The URL is valid for one hour after you generate it. To access the application UI after that hour elapses, you must invoke the API again to generate a new URL.

member.name: T:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobDriver
member.summary: The driver that the job runs on.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobDriver.Hive
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Hive.
The job driver parameters specified for Hive.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobDriver.SparkSubmit
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SparkSubmit.
The job driver parameters specified for Spark.

member.name: T:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun
member.summary: Information about a job run. A job run is a unit of work, such as a Spark JAR, Hive query, or SparkSQL query, that you submit to an Amazon EMR Serverless application.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.ApplicationId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ApplicationId.
The ID of the application the job is running on.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.Arn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Arn.
The execution role ARN of the job run.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.BilledResourceUtilization
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BilledResourceUtilization.
The aggregate vCPU, memory, and storage that Amazon Web Services has billed for the job run. The billed resources include a 1-minute minimum usage for workers, plus additional storage over 20 GB per worker. Note that billed resources do not include usage for idle pre-initialized workers.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.ConfigurationOverrides
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ConfigurationOverrides.
The configuration settings that are used to override default configuration.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.CreatedAt
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreatedAt.
The date and time when the job run was created.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.CreatedBy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreatedBy.
The user who created the job run.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.ExecutionRole
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionRole.
The execution role ARN of the job run.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.ExecutionTimeoutMinutes
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionTimeoutMinutes.
Returns the job run timeout value from the StartJobRun call. If no timeout was specified, then it returns the default timeout of 720 minutes.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.JobDriver
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobDriver.
The job driver for the job run.

member.name: P:Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.JobRun.JobRunId
member.summary:

member.name: T:Amazon.EMRServerless.AmazonEMRServerlessClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing EMRServerless
Amazon EMR Serverless is a new deployment option for Amazon EMR. Amazon EMR Serverless provides a serverless runtime environment that simplifies running analytics applications using the latest open source frameworks such as Apache Spark and Apache Hive. With Amazon EMR Serverless, you don’t have to configure, optimize, secure, or operate clusters to run applications with these frameworks.
The API reference to Amazon EMR Serverless is emr-serverless. The emr-serverless prefix is used in the following scenarios:
It is the prefix in the CLI commands for Amazon EMR Serverless. For example, aws emr-serverless start-job-run.
It is the prefix before IAM policy actions for Amazon EMR Serverless. For example, "Action": ["emr-serverless:StartJobRun"]. For more information, see Policy actions for Amazon EMR Serverless.
It is the prefix used in Amazon EMR Serverless service endpoints. For example, emr-serverless.us-east-2.amazonaws.com.

member.name: M:Amazon.EMRServerless.AmazonEMRServerlessClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonEMRServerlessClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.EMRServerless.AmazonEMRServerlessClient.GetDashboardForJobRunAsync(Amazon.EMRServerless.Model.GetDashboardForJobRunRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Creates and returns a URL that you can use to access the application UIs for a job run.
For jobs in a running state, the application UI is a live user interface such as the Spark or Tez web UI. For completed jobs, the application UI is a persistent application user interface such as the Spark History Server or persistent Tez UI.
The URL is valid for one hour after you generate it. To access the application UI after that hour elapses, you must invoke the API again to generate a new URL.
